nodes.claim: Logical/epistemic: If benchmarks are biased, many reported gains may not generalize, forcing a re-evaluation of past claims and a reweighting of evidence toward real-world performance.

nodes.label: HUMAN: Individual researchers and teams may optimi...
nodes.claim: HUMAN: Individual researchers and teams may optimize for benchmarks due to personal incentives, leading to selective reporting and cherry-picking results.

nodes.label: INSTITUTIONAL: Benchmark-centric evaluation cultur...
nodes.claim: INSTITUTIONAL: Benchmark-centric evaluation culture (leaderboards, grants, and prestige tied to benchmark wins) reinforces narrow progress signals.

nodes.label: EVIDENTIAL: Benchmark datasets may be contaminated...
nodes.claim: EVIDENTIAL: Benchmark datasets may be contaminated with distributional biases, label noise, or non-stationary properties that inflate apparent performance.

nodes.label: EPISTEMOLOGICAL: Assumptions that benchmark perfor...
nodes.claim: EPISTEMOLOGICAL: Assumptions that benchmark performance correlates with real-world generalization are tacitly embedded in methodology, risking misinterpretation of progress.

nodes.label: Emotional/psychological: Researchers experience he...
nodes.claim: Emotional/psychological: Researchers experience heightened anxiety and competition, potentially reducing collaboration and openness about negative results.

nodes.label: HUMAN: Individual researchers and teams are motiva...

nodes.label: INSTITUTIONAL: Promotion criteria, grant scoring r...

nodes.label: EPISTEMOLOGICAL: Community norms and incentives ar...

nodes.label: Logical/operational: Funding and publication biase...
nodes.claim: Logical/operational: Funding and publication biases would demand more stringent replication, preregistration, and negative-result reporting to avoid misleading progress narratives.

nodes.label: HUMAN: Researchers are motivated by career incenti...
nodes.claim: HUMAN: Researchers are motivated by career incentives, prestige, and fear of obscurity, which biases what results are pursued and highlighted.

nodes.label: INSTITUTIONAL: Granting agencies, journals, and co...
nodes.claim: INSTITUTIONAL: Granting agencies, journals, and conferences reward novelty and positive results with publicity, funding, and rapid career advancement, shaping research behavior.

nodes.label: EVIDENTIAL: The literature disproportionately feat...
nodes.claim: EVIDENTIAL: The literature disproportionately features studies with significant positive results due to publication bias and selective reporting, distorting the apparent solvability signal.

nodes.label: PRACTICAL: Limited funding and time pressures push...
nodes.claim: PRACTICAL: Limited funding and time pressures push teams to optimize for noticeable progress and favorable metrics rather than robust, long-horizon solvability demonstrations.

nodes.label: HUMAN: Individual researchers’ confirmation bias a...
nodes.claim: HUMAN: Individual researchers’ confirmation bias and motivational biases as they pursue career advancement, funding, or prestige by producing alignable results.

nodes.label: EVIDENTIAL: Data selection and benchmark design th...
nodes.claim: EVIDENTIAL: Data selection and benchmark design that favor results supporting prevailing beliefs about solvability, including selective reporting and cherry-picking of favorable experiments.

nodes.label: EPISTEMOLOGICAL: Methodological overconfidence or ...
nodes.claim: EPISTEMOLOGICAL: Methodological overconfidence or reliance on optimistic theoretical guarantees without rigorous falsification tests, leading to biased interpretation of results.

nodes.label: Benchmark-driven optimism would deflate as researc...
nodes.claim: Benchmark-driven optimism would deflate as researchers recognize gaps between benchmarks and real-world tasks, leading to recalibration of funding and research agendas.

nodes.label: EVIDENTIAL: Benchmarks are not fully representativ...
